instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.GPUVCORE_EN: What is GPUVCORE_EN? GPUVCORE_EN enables GPU VCORE when it is high, a power rail necessary for the GPU to function so you can get an image on the screen. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no GPUVCORE
threads.message:
This machine was going to a blank/dead screen while in use, more and more often.  Eventually it got to the point where it would chime on re-boot, but the lcd would show no image.

Tried re-soldering/replacing <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, then when that didn't help, realized I needed to stop guessing and start analyzing.

First thing I noticed was that I knocked off several components around <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> (I know, rookie mistake - didn't have the air turned down enough)  After I replaced those, I checked for the GPU power rails from sheet 88 of the schematic and measured the following:

P3V3GPU - 1.3 millivolts
P1V8GPU - 1.805 volts
GPUVCORE - 0.0 millivolts
P1V35GPUFB - 0.0 millivolts
<SIGNAL>P1V05_S0GPU</SIGNAL> - 0.0 millivolts

I could use a clue to understand how to troubleshoot the different power rails.

With the board out of the chassis, connecting the power adapter, the light comes on, fans spin up and over the course of 2 minutes or so, gradually go from low speed to high speed, and pretty loud.  Not sure if that is normal.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no GPUVCORE
threads.message:
Ok, after I thought about a while, that P1V8GPU measurement I took must have been wrong.  I measured at pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R1600</RESISTOR>, which I see now is associated with the CPU power rail, not for GPU.

I did go and check the following enable signals for GPU at the resistors around <CHIP>U9100</CHIP> - and the signals are all not there.  Wouldn't these be present when the bare board is powered up?  Or are they just momentary after the board first starts?

<SIGNAL>P3V3GPU_EN</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R9121</RESISTOR> - 1.0 millivolts
<SIGNAL>P1V8GPU_EN</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R9122</RESISTOR> - 1.0 millivolts
<SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R9123</RESISTOR> - 1.0 millivolts
P1V35GPUFB_EN at <RESISTOR>R9124</RESISTOR> - 1.0 millivolts
<SIGNAL>P1V05_S0GPU_EN</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R9125</RESISTOR> - 1.1 millivolts

I also confirmed USB activity on a bootable flash drive.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no GPUVCORE
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Be sure <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is properly soldered and check all traces and surrounding components.
Post voltage for pins 16, 17, 25, 38.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no GPUVCORE
threads.message:
Appreciate the welcome!  Thanks!

I have again checked <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and surrounding components.  I have made diode-mode measurements for each pin, and compared to a known good board.  I previously found a bad <RESISTOR>R8900</RESISTOR> this way, and replaced it.  I have a few other maybe-bad/maybe-not-bad readings I'm not sure what to make of, if it would help.

pin 16 - 5.00 
pin 17 - 12.53
pin 25 - 5.00
pin 38 - 0.001 (my MM reads 1.0 millivolts)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no GPUVCORE
threads.message:
GPU is probably bad and not worth to solve this problem.
Is better to disable GPU, not too complicated on this board; hardware mod already posted on the forum.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no GPUVCORE
threads.message: Ahh, thanks - that's a shame.  I found the hardware mod you referenced, so I may try that.
